7.85.text:
This story starts in September last year.
A few days before the start of the shooting

13.97.text:
season, George asks us over to film some driven
boar shooting... Not in Germany, but Sussex.

21.43.text:
The reason? Unprecedented boar damage to his
cover crops. It's put him in an impossible

27.29.text:
I hate it to be honest. If I am honest it
is not something, I love to see them about,

34.84.text:
but I think they are a wonderful animal, but
he being a conservationist I also understand

40.54.text:
that stuff has to be controlled. I wouldn't
want to see massive damage done everywhere

45.91.text: and I wouldn't want to see the last one eradicated.

49.03.text:
With only two beaters, it's going to be hard
going but George is desperate to move them

53.33.text:
on. He positions himself near a damaged fence
line, a semi auto filled with solid slugs.

60.18.text:
This is one load he isn't prepared to put
through his competition Perazzi.

64.59.text:
The guys work through the maize crop but the
only thing that shows itself is a fox who

68.89.text: doesn't realise how lucky it is.

72.32.text:
The beating line, such as it is, pushes through
another couple on the estate, but they're

78.63.text:
The alternative strategy is even less appealing
to George. Lamping them.

83.32.text:
Tonight the rifle I am using is a Tikka T3,
a .308 calibre. Sussex police have a minimum

96.02.text:
requirement of .270 to shoot wild boar and
you have to have it on your licence to be

100.57.text:
able to go after them. So that is one of the
reasons I have been called in to do this,

105.10.text:
because I have got the permission to shoot
the ground and I have got boar on my licence.

109.32.text:
So we are meeting all the requirements tonight
to be able to go after them in a legal manner

115.56.text: and hopefully we will get a chance at one.

119.72.text:
George has a .308 and .243 with him - keeping
his options open and with good reason...

126.09.text:
The night starts with some foxing action - George
not only has to protect his cover crops but

131.08.text:
his birds too. As you'd expect it's a well
executed shot.

135.65.text:
When the light touched it, it was obviously
a little bit lamp shy, it had been shot at

139.65.text:
before I would think and it turned and ran
here round about ten yards, stopped and looked

144.34.text:
over its shoulder and that was just enough
to get a shot at it. It was about 250 yards,

149.98.text:
a nice shot. A safe background into the bank.
Nice start.

154.20.text:
200 yards further on in the super smooth electric
Polaris, he bags another just yards from the

161.94.text: pens. This one's a big lad.

164.45.text:
Very, very big fox. Probably one of the biggest
foxes I have seen. It is a real big dog fox,

173.61.text:
thick set as well, lot of muscle. That will
have been a real hunter killer. It was a good

180.94.text:
On the other side of the estate we get our
first sight of pig. They cross along the fence

187.10.text:
line and disappear into the wood. George considers
a shot but lets them go. He isn't happy taking

193.74.text:
a shot at this range at night. The last thing
he wants is an injured boar with no means

200.58.text:
That was the last chance George had before
the game season started. Tonight, four-and-a-half

205.69.text: months later, we're on boar patrol again.

208.51.text:
They are creating so much damage for me at
the moment I have got to go and do something

212.22.text:
about it. I don't think there are huge amounts,
but I think to just take one or maybe two

222.27.text:
out is the way forward to hopefully move them
on and push them back in the woods where they

226.29.text:
can root up anemone roots and bulbs and those
sorts of things. In a normal year it wouldn't

233.79.text:
be a problem because they would be on the
acorns, hard on the acorns in the hard wood,

236.95.text:
but there are no acorns at all this year,
no chestnuts. So consequently they are out

242.49.text:
after everything they can get their hands
on.

245.26.text:
The damage to the ground and the feeders is
clear to see - and George is confident we'll

249.42.text:
spot one tonight. However, just like last
time, the fox is the first target and George

255.03.text: is keen to see it drop.

256.76.text: And this is the reason why?

258.61.text:
Now we just shot that fox there now and he
was working his way up through the park and

262.87.text:
the reason he is working his way up through
the park is it has been a windy night some

266.18.text:
of these pheasants have been blown out of
the roost. If you look over there in the light

270.33.text:
now there is pheasant on the ground which
has been blown off the roost. See that. If

274.70.text:
a pheasant gets blown off the roost, that
will be it now he won't go back up and roost

279.62.text:
We drive through the maize: - the boars' acorn-substitute
this winter - but there's no sign. However,

285.30.text: the foxes are not being so shy.

290.75.text:
If I see a fox and get an opportunity to get
a fox I have got to take it, otherwise I am

298.20.text:
George drops one after another - the hum of
the Polaris keeping them sitting pretty. There's

303.88.text:
even a pair running together. George gets
the first. The second runs but a drive through

310.09.text: some other fields accounts for her too.

313.41.text:
There's frustration for all. George needs
to scare these animals back into the woods

318.04.text:
so they don't interrupt the gathering-up work
at the end of the season. So we will be back

322.99.text:
for our elusive Sussex boar in the next few
days.
